Cooling water systems are widely used across industry and contribute to a large water consumption. The reduction of this consumption is the target of several studies that seek solutions for sustainable development. Process Integration (IP) proves to be an important tool for optimizing cooling networks, reducing water consumption and adopting a strategic reuse of cooling water streams within the system. Within the IP toolkit, the Cooling Water Sources Diagram (DFAR) makes it possible to minimize the use of w ater resources, in addition to making it possible to evaluate the system in a holistic way. In order to expand the industrial application of DFAR, a computational code was developed to allow the analysis of large cooling networks in a short period. This co de was used to analyze a network of cooling systems with two different systems and 28 continuous consumers. The savings obtained through DFAR were compared with the relative cost of the necessary arrangement modifications for its application, with the obje ctive of verifying two financial parameters, the payback time and the ROI. It was found that, in line with sustainable development trends, the implementation of the proposal obtained with DFAR was favorable, with a low payback time and high ROI for the ana lyzed system. In addition, a critical analysis of the DFAR methodology was carried out, verifying the influence that the proposed variations on the cold side of consumers can generate in the thermal exchange of each exchange (considered constant in the app lication of the methodology) and, consequently, in the process - hot side. It was verified that, for the analyzed plate exchanger, the variation on the cold side had an influence on the thermal load of the exchanger.
